Award.AwardTitle: CMG Research: A Copula-Based Probabilistic Approach for Space-Time Characterization of Droughts
Award.AbstractNarration:
Drought is one of the most expensive and the least understood of natural disasters. The current process of drought specification through the Drought Monitor is based on drought indices that are constructed from various individual data sources, primarily rainfall, soil moisture, and streamflows. However, these indices do not account for spatial and temporal structure of the hydrologic variables. Researchers have been thwarted in building statistical models of the highly correlated hydrologic variables because of lack of sound methods for representing dependence between hydrologic variables and for reducing the dimensionality of such datasets to manageable levels. This research will develop innovative schemes that utilize copulas for modeling hydrologic distributions under a set of conditional independence assumptions represented by sparse graphical models. In the copula approach, the joint distribution of variables is modeled as a function of the transformed marginal distributions of the variables, so that the joint nature of the variability can be considered separately from the unconditional probabilities of the individual variables. The project will use this statistical technique to develop a joint drought indicator that draws on information from multiple spatial sources and preserves the proper dependence relationships among the hydrological variables. The key hypothesis is that a copula-based approach will 1) provide a joint description of droughts and that such a description will enable us to study the spatial scales of these droughts over a range of time-windows to establish temporal dependence, and 2) enable probabilistic classification of drought status and evaluation of the chance of recovering from a current drought. This two-year project will specifically address drought in Indiana at different temporal scales, although the methods developed will be applicable to droughts in all regions and on all spatial scales.

The research has strong potential benefit for society given the enormous human and monetary consequences of drought, and the results of this research will be of interest to a wide user community. In particular, the research will develop easily interpretable maps and characterizations of water deficit and drought, which will be developed for use by national and state agencies as well as a broader community of climatologists, hydrologists, and stakeholders. The project will also support the education of graduate and undergraduate students, who will receive training in the multidisciplinary field of statistical hydrology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A major thrust of this project was to gain a better understanding of the space-time scales of droughts and to develop spatio-temporal probabilistic models for characterizing droughts from historical measurements of hydrologic variables such as rainfall, streamflows, and soil moisture. To capture the complex nature of dependencies that exist between hydrologic variables, advanced statistical methods were developed and deployed in this research. Specific applications included: (i) drought hydrologic triggers were identified by recognizing patterns in past hydrologic variables; (ii) a conditional-independence model was utilized for designing parsimonious models as data tend to be limited; and (iii) soil-moisture was utilized for better representation
of agricultural droughts. Results from this project have been disseminated in several papers and conference presentations. A workshop early in the project helped learn from stakeholders (scientists in other fields, water planers, state
decision makers, authors of the U.S. drought monitor, etc.) about community
needs.

We introduced a new paradigm of probabilistic classification of drought
states. This is a new concept in hydrology. Current drought indicators do not
account for temporal dependence, have little generative properties, and do not provide any uncertainty with their classification scheme. In this research, methods for uncertainty in drought classification were developed along with the severity of drought, thus allowing for more informed allocation of resources by federal and state agencies for combating droughts. There are two challenges that still remain to be addressed. The method allows for quantification of model uncertainty, but dos not currently encompass uncertainties that results from measurements, primarily because these have not been properly quantified. Secondly, the question of how this uncertainty information can help decision makers remains to be fully explored. Results from this study have implications in statistics and computer learning, since new algorithms will have to be developed to understand drought characterization, and better methods will have to be designed for parameter estimation when data tend to be sparse. Social scientists will have to be engaged to determine how to best use information on uncertainty and the risk that society is willing to incur in the case of droughts.

Several graduate students have been funded on this project. Some have completed their degrees and have sought academic positions, while other have been employed in the private sector. The project also benefited from international collaboration from a research scientist in India who spent six month of his time with the PI on a government fellowship.
